    If bit then

    This optimisation came up in a consulting job for my company, CruxML. A common pattern in embedded programming or high-level synthesis is if-bit-then, i.e. test a bit and modify a variable depending on the result.

    Here is an example in C:

    unsigned a = 0x23, x = 0x86;

...
    if (a & 1)
	    x = x op q;

    (where op is some operation like + but could be more complicated). This can be implemented in a number of ways. A common one is:

        x = (a & 1) ? x op q : x;

    An alternative, less well known way to do this is:

        x = x op (-(a & 1) & q)

    This relies on the fact that a & 1 only has two possible outputs, 1 or 0. Moreover, -1 = 0xffffffff and -0 == 0 so -(a & 1) & q either evaluates to q or 0.

    This identity may be advantageous depending on the situation, particularly for optimising inner loops of time-critical applications.

    Tags: embedded

    Categories: cruxml
